content.description: Sit or stand start this burly overhanging flared problem.  For a fun challenge, start on your back with your feet in the low pod, sit up, and finish.
content.protection: A pad or two.
content.location: This is the left-leaning, flared crack on the big boulder touching the left side of the road right before you reach the formation.

content.description:
This is a 4 bolt, short sport route on the ass end of East LA left of

H & S Chimney

on the corner.

I've never stepped foot on this route. Someone please provide any additional information about name, who put it up and the grade. Thanks.
content.protection: 4 draws + 2 for the anchor.
content.location:
It is left of

H & S Chimney

on the corner. Park at the last campsite. Walk off to the north.

content.description: Right-leaning, slabby, flared crack.  Starts small offwidth, but if you're tall you can reach past that to good jams.  Crack gradually shuts down and turns into a crystal climb for the last 4 feet or so.  A little on the dirty side.
content.protection: A pad or two, and a spotter.  The crux comes low, but the crack gets a little weird higher up.
content.location: Across the corridor from the layback flake.  Walkoff/downclimb to climber's left.

content.description:
This is a crack that begins on a ledge and jogs right and up through the obvious butt crack. It has 3 distinct cruxes: a slap move, then a flairing hand crack, then a lieback grunt at the top.

I can only claim to have fallen all over this climb. My two buddies who led it clean called it 5.11c. If anyone can please provide info about the FA or name or rating, please chime in.

Lots of dirt and plant matter was pulled from this guy, but there is no chance we're the first.
content.protection: A blue TCU for the start keeps you off the deck. Back it up, and you'll be fine for the rest of the route. Place 2 small guys for the start and #0.75 - #2 for the rest. Save a couple #1s and/or #2s for an anchor at the top. DO NOT toprope this route. It will eat your rope (the crack) and scour it. Belay your second from above.
content.location:
This is left of

Unknown Sport Route

on the ass end of East LA. Park at last campsite, and walk around the south end. Hike off to the North.

content.description: This short interesting mushroom boulder problem calls for the reverse flush. A very Vedauwoo-esq move. Wear pants.
content.protection: A pad is nice to jump back down on -- and some pants.
content.location: Just down the road past the 'Scrappy Crack' you'll see the toilet bowl on the left.

content.description: Slotsky is a short chimney with a fun exit.
content.protection: Finger/hand sized cams.
content.location:
This ascends the chimney splitting the south face, just right of two bolt slab route

Aretsky

.

content.description: Sit on top of the lower boulder above the little cave, downclimb the offwidth flare towards the ground, traverse the cave on good jams, and invert-offwidth back up the other side. I preferred climbing southward, but laps can be done in either direction.
content.protection: One pad is sufficient. Elbow/knee pads are nice too. The rock is sharp.
content.location: This ascends two boulders forming a cave on the Northwest edge of the East LA 700-HB cul-de-sac.

content.description:
This is the right-arching hand crack just left of

Casual Corner

. When the crack turns horizontal, follow two bolts up the slabby face.
content.protection: Thin hands and hand-sized pieces are best. There are two bolts up high. As of August 2016, there should be a rappable two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This is 10 feet left of

Casual Corner

.

content.description: The crux is just before pulling over the top.  A bit scary if you aren't solid on this grade and type of climbing. A nice slab exercise, trust those feet.
content.protection: A pad and spotter might be nice.
content.location: Located on the separate slabby rock to the west of the main Party Dome.  Faces north. Walk off to the south. Multiple slabby options exist, this is the further right ~10 foot line.

content.description: There are a few balancy moves on the problem and a fall from near the top wouldn't be pretty.  Climbs on slightly better holds than the right side, a few crystals and some trust in the feet send you over the top.
content.protection: A pad and spotter would help, better yet, don't fall.
content.location: Just west of the beginning the the part dome is the small slab with multiple lines, but two distinct options stand out.  The left climbs to and off of a relatively large crystal near the bottom of the climb.  The slab has a rodent sized undercut below it, especially on the left side. Walk off to the south.

content.description: This obvious and fun right facing layback flake is a good warm up for nearby bouldering. A little tall for beginners, with the hardest moves at 3/4 height.  Topout isn't too bad.
content.protection: A pad and spot.
content.location: This flake is located in the corridor between the early slabs and the main dome.  Faces east towards the dome. Easy downclimb to the south.

content.description: This is a really good crack problem. It starts out as an overhanging finger crack in a hallway, then you can either step off on the rock behind you or for full value, top out the easy 5.8 above. From the top, an easy corridor leads back down to the base. For extra value, sit start the problem, which provides a definite starting point, and bumps the grade to more solid V8. There are many different interpretations of the stand start, with varying grades. This is a very fun thin finger crack. Bring tape.
content.protection: A pad, though for the crux start you can just step back if you are going to fall, and after that a pad would be useless.
content.location: This is the tall crack splitting the back (south) wall of the formation, the bottom finger crack hidden behind a slab.

content.description:
This is actually the highball finish to the "Crap Artist". Begin standing on top of the slab and climb the obvious arching hand crack to the top of the Party Dome.

From user Orphaned:

Hang Five ascends a right-arching crack splitting the south face. Step over the dropoff and into crack with the help of some good hand jams, then move to flaring fists as the crack rolls over to mellower angle and widens.
content.protection: Cams to a #3.

content.description: Start climbing a wide crack with some stemming and smearing at the start. Work into a chimney that narrows as you go up. Crux is probably the top out depending on your body size. Short climb but worth doing if you like this sort of climbing or are camping at East L.A.
content.protection: Standard rack to #6 Friend. Something larger than a #6 Friend to sew it up though not needed for safety.
content.location:
Crack/chimney immediately to the left of ?Hang Five?. Scramble up the slab and step across the gap in the rocks to begin. Belay at any suitable crack on top of the formation.

Descend via a walk off or single rope rap off 2 bolts and rings around the corner to climber's left of top out. Some down climbing necessary to reach rap anchors.

content.description: Pull overhang via big knobby crystals up  onto the green slab.  The climbing above is about 5.8 but gets a little highball.
content.protection: No gear, just bouldering.
content.location: This is the large green boulder to the south as you approach Nat's Three Star area.  Vear right off of two track, as you come up on Nat's, towards green boulder next to short 25 ft. arete with bolts missing their hangers.

content.description: Try this enchanting, left-sloping, capacious crack.  After breezing through the crack, high step over a headwall for the finish.  I recommend doing this third for the Knabe trifecta after the Casual Corner routes.
content.protection: May want a couple of larger pieces (#5 or #6 Friends).
content.location:
This is maybe a tenth of a furlong uphill from

Casual Corner Junior

and on a southeast-facing wall.  The quickest descent is a short downclimb to climber's left.

content.description: Climb this perfect 5.3 hand crack in the right facing dihedral.  Then move forward over a class 1 slab to either a pine needle infested crack descent or climb one of the cracks above a bush to an easier descent.
content.protection: Light Rack
content.location: This route is on the opposite side of the rock from Slotsky.  Walk around to the north side through some aspens and look for crack in photo.

content.description: Short off-width, the rock was crumbly.  The crux is the bulge at the top.
content.protection: Mid-sized cam, one large one for the top.  Anchor on top around big bulge.

content.description:
Climb the hands/offwidth crack to where it goes horizontal.  Then climb a face (10 feet) to your right to the top.  We found the crux to be the end of the main crack.  A #6 Friend can be placed here to sew it up.  Overall, a pretty good climb, warm up on junior, hit this one then get beat up on

Das Knabestreich

.
content.protection: Larger gear for the main crack,  a small nut or cam for the face finish.
content.location: Just to the left of Junior through a hallway.  To descend walk west then scramble to your left.  You can also exit at the end of the crack via easy chimneying.

content.description: Aretsky is a slab route with good crystals for feet right where you need them.
content.protection: 2 bolts, no anchors.
content.location:
This is a bolted slab on the southeast face, just left of

Slotsky

(chimney).
